> The technique is one that I have found useful at least once,
> which is to put a public static inner class that extends
> junit.framework.TestCase in the
> class under test.  This gives the inner class full access to the outer
> class's private methods and members, while allowing the inner
> class to be an
> instance of a JUnit test case.  I sent an example of this to
> this list a few
> weeks ago.  Another handy thing is that when you compile the
> outer class,
> the inner test case is produced in a separate class file
> which can be safely
> deleted when packaging the outer class for production
> (because the outer
> class makes no references to the static inner class).

I have recently used a similar technique for legacy code I wanted to test
but had no chance to refactor. Because my tests reside in their own packages
and I didn't want to break this pattern, I decided to implement a test
interface as an inner class:

public class ClassToTest {
  private void methodToTest() {
    ...
  }

  public class TestInterface {
    public void testMethod() {
      methodToTest();
    }
}

This way I can call the private method via

(instanceToTest.new TestInterface()).testMethod();

I have to admit that this code is somewhat ugly, but I am happy with this -
after all I think it *is* a code smell... ;-)
